issues.title: Remove "php" app
issues.body:
The "php" django app only exists for the tests it contains, but the tests are highly data dependent and are somewhat unlikely to still pass (I didn't try).

I suggest removing them.

repo.description: An improved version of Mozilla's download load balancer Bouncer, with a user interface written in Django/Python.

repo.name: tuxedo
repo.description: An improved version of Mozilla's download load balancer Bouncer, with a user interface written in Django/Python.

issue_comments.body: This was merged.

Good job! However, try entering a broken IP address (such as: "10.0.0.345"), you'll get a 500 error. Can you catch it and turn it into an error on the field in question?

r-

So there is a bug in ipaddr. We get a NameError because it tries to throw IPv6ValidationError where in fact it should have IPv6IpValidationError. I'm gonna file a bug for that.

Otherwise we should receive an IPv4IpValidationError.
Actually, we use ipaddr 2.0.0 but the current version is 2.1.9. Maybe we should update.
Looks like you might need to create a vendor library: http://playdoh.readthedocs.org/en/latest/packages.html
btw, the code looks good, r+
Updated exception handling.
looks good! r+
Yeah I missed that too in my code review, arghl. Thanks for fixing it! r+
I think you need a South migration to add the new field to the database.
Looks good so far, minus the migration. I asked Brandon to talk to @Rik about how to create a South migration.
Updated. Please r?

This looks good; what concerns me a little is that this won't run cleanly on our production server: It'll try and create the geoip tables and will fail doing that. But perhaps we can't assume this would work anyway. Thus, when asking IT to update production, you'll need to tell them what SQL to run.
Should it be two migrations? One for the current layout and then one for the fallback field?
I'll make sure and assist IT when the time comes.

The migration that I ran contained the new field. I can create a migration without it and merge in a new migration if that would be easier. It honestly never occurred to me. Would that make this easier?

Yes that would make things easier I think. Then it's up to you/IT to "fake" the initial migration before actually running the second one (there's a South command for pretending to run a migration as just marking it as "run").
Closing for a branch to be used instead.
All right this looks good to me. The duplicate query is a little sad, but ah well.
r+
I'm also a bit worried that tables will be locked when running the migrations. We don't want to block downloads. Need to sync with IT on that.

Locking tables with DDL statements is true (sheeri surely knows more), though considering how small these tables are, it should be a nonissue. For huge tables, this is in fact a real issue if you can't access it for an hour or worse.
That should be feature complete.
If this is r+ can we get it committed? I can't merge it myself. :(
Sure, sorry about that.
I like this! If you answer my question about the logic behind user.is_staff, then r+
Also, it looks you can't merge this automatically anymore, might have to rebase before landing
r-, see comment
Why `prev_sys_path`? You create it and then don't use it for anything.
remove that unused var and :shipit:

commit_comments.body:
Hm, I think the usual syntax is:

`-e git://....`

Take a look at zamboni's requirements files, for example.

review_comments.body: Would it make sense if you didn't query for the fallback region unless you need it? It'd save us a lot of DB queries, for all the cases when the primary region is not rejected.

review_comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -2,7 +2,7 @@ Django==1.2
 MySQL-python==1.2.3c1
 ipaddr==2.0.0
 Markdown==2.0.3
-texttable==0.7.0
+texttable==0.8.1
review_comments.body: Just curious: Does this have anything to do with this patch? (By all means keep it in)

review_comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -2,7 +2,7 @@ Django==1.2
 MySQL-python==1.2.3c1
 ipaddr==2.0.0
 Markdown==2.0.3
-texttable==0.7.0
+texttable==0.8.1
review_comments.body: It was the only way I could get the PIP requirements to install. It doesn't have anything to do with this patch other than that.

 MySQL-python==1.2.3c1
 ipaddr==2.0.0
 Markdown==2.0.3

+texttable==0.8.1
review_comments.body: great, thanks for fixing it.
Hm, I wonder if we can avoid hitting the DB twice for this?

review_comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -1,18 +1,20 @@
-from django.contrib.auth.decorators import login_required
-from django.shortcuts import render_to_response
+from django.contrib.auth.decorators import login_required, permission_required
+from django.contrib.auth.models import User as DjangoUser
+from django.http import HttpResponseForbidden
+from django.shortcuts import render_to_response, get_object_or_404, get_list_or_404
review_comments.body: nit-pick: alphabetize :)

review_comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -31,3 +33,22 @@ def profile(request):
     return render_to_response('registration/profile.html', data,
                               context_instance=RequestContext(request))
 
+
+@login_required
+def own_profile(request):
+    return profile(request, request.user)
+
+
+@permission_required('users.change_user')
+def profile_edition(request, pk):
+    django_user = get_object_or_404(DjangoUser, pk=pk)
+    if django_user.is_staff:
review_comments.body: I am not sure I understand the logic here, can you explain? This is decorated with the change_user permission. So once we get to this point, we know the active user is allowed to edit other users. However, if that user is a staff member (= has access to the admin pages in any way), then you reject them here?

review_comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -31,3 +33,22 @@ def profile(request):
     return render_to_response('registration/profile.html', data,
                               context_instance=RequestContext(request))
 
+
+@login_required
+def own_profile(request):
+    return profile(request, request.user)
+
+
+@permission_required('users.change_user')

review_comments.body: Nope
Looks like a test variable that slipped.

That's actually intentional. The $client_ip variable is referenced before it's used elsewhere in the code. PHP doesn't consider this a fatal error, but does emit a notice, which I corrected by initializing the variable before it would be referenced by other code. This will be overwritten later when it discovers the client IP address.
Ah, nevermind then ;)
Just remove the line then :)

uh, this indentation is off.

Also, I guess a comment wouldn't have hurt here.

This chooses which locale should be tested. Historically we test the alphabetically last locale available, because rsync generally runs in alphabetical order... the thinking is that if the last locale exists, then the other do too. It's inherently a trade-off designed to avoid having to test every single locale individually.

I read this as "if seamonkey, and if it's version 2.0.5 or 2.0.6, check zh-CN. For all other versions, check tr".

Based on wandering around here: http://download.cdn.mozilla.net/pub/seamonkey/releases/ ... it appears that Seamonkey did indeed have zh-CN support for those two versions, and potentially a few others. However it was not consistent. 2.1 did not have it... 2.13 (current) has zh-CN and zh-TW. In many versions, "tr" was indeed the alphabetically-last locale.

However, for the most part it doesn't matter anymore. The lone mirrors are reverse-proxying CDNs, not rsync-based. The logic of checking the last locale no longer holds any real value... any locale is just as good as any other. We still need to check _a_ locale, but it doesn't matter which one.

That's actually intentional. The $client_ip variable is referenced before it's used elsewhere in the code. PHP doesn't consider this a fatal error, but does emit a notice, which I corrected by initializing the variable before it would be referenced by other code. This will be overwritten later when it discovers the client IP address.
Ah, nevermind then ;)
Just remove the line then :)

uh, this indentation is off.

Also, I guess a comment wouldn't have hurt here.

This chooses which locale should be tested. Historically we test the alphabetically last locale available, because rsync generally runs in alphabetical order... the thinking is that if the last locale exists, then the other do too. It's inherently a trade-off designed to avoid having to test every single locale individually.

I read this as "if seamonkey, and if it's version 2.0.5 or 2.0.6, check zh-CN. For all other versions, check tr".

Based on wandering around here: http://download.cdn.mozilla.net/pub/seamonkey/releases/ ... it appears that Seamonkey did indeed have zh-CN support for those two versions, and potentially a few others. However it was not consistent. 2.1 did not have it... 2.13 (current) has zh-CN and zh-TW. In many versions, "tr" was indeed the alphabetically-last locale.

However, for the most part it doesn't matter anymore. The lone mirrors are reverse-proxying CDNs, not rsync-based. The logic of checking the last locale no longer holds any real value... any locale is just as good as any other. We still need to check _a_ locale, but it doesn't matter which one.
